skill.name: networkx
skill.description: Comprehensive toolkit for creating, analyzing, and visualizing complex networks and graphs in Python. Use when working with network/graph data structures, analyzing relationships between entities, computing graph algorithms (shortest paths, centrality, clustering), detecting communities, generating synthetic networks, or visualizing network topologies. Applicable to social networks, biological networks, transportation systems, citation networks, and any domain involving pairwise relationships.
skill.summary: Comprehensive toolkit for creating, analyzing, and visualizing complex networks and graphs in Python...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: No data theft or malicious execution patterns were found. The content is instructional and focuses on NetworkX usage. Links are documentation references only.

content.user_title: Build and analyze networks with NetworkX
content.value_statement: I need to analyze relationships in graph data but I lack reliable examples. This skill gives me clear NetworkX steps for creation, analysis, and visualization.
actual_capabilities: Create Graph, DiGraph, MultiGraph, and MultiDiGraph with nodes and edges
Run shortest paths, centrality, clustering, and community detection algorithms
Generate synthetic networks such as Erdos Renyi, Barabasi Albert, and Watts Strogatz
Read and write graphs in edge list, GraphML, GML, and JSON formats
Visualize networks with layouts and styling using Matplotlib
limitations: Requires NetworkX installed in the Python environment
Large graphs can require high memory and slow layout computation
Visualization examples depend on Matplotlib or optional libraries
Does not provide real time streaming graph updates

use_cases.title: Measure influence in networks
use_cases.description: Compute centrality and clustering metrics to identify key nodes in relationship data.

use_cases.title: Model synthetic networks
use_cases.description: Generate classic and random graph models to test hypotheses and compare structures.

use_cases.title: Export graph formats
use_cases.description: Convert graphs to GraphML, GML, or CSV for downstream tools and storage.

prompt_templates.title: Start a simple graph
prompt_templates.scenario: Beginner needs a basic NetworkX example
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to create a small undirected graph, add nodes and edges with attributes, and list its nodes and edges.

prompt_templates.title: Compute shortest path
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants a path with weights
prompt_templates.prompt: Given a weighted graph, show how to compute shortest path length and the path between two nodes.

prompt_templates.title: Detect communities
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain how to run greedy modularity communities and summarize the resulting groups.

prompt_templates.title: Visualize with styling
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a spring layout, color nodes by degree, scale sizes by centrality, and save a high resolution image.

output_examples.input: Analyze this small network for key nodes and draw it with a clear layout.
output: Most central nodes are 2 and 4 based on degree and betweenness
The graph has two tightly connected clusters
Saved a labeled spring layout image with node sizes scaled by centrality

best_practices: Set random seeds for graph generators and layouts to ensure reproducibility
Use sparse matrices for large sparse graphs to reduce memory use
Validate connectivity and graph type before running algorithms
anti_patterns: Running heavy layouts on very large graphs without sampling
Ignoring edge weights when the analysis depends on costs
Mixing directed and undirected assumptions in metrics

faq.question: Is this compatible with current NetworkX versions?
faq.answer: Yes, it uses standard NetworkX APIs that are stable in current releases.

faq.question: What are the size limits for graphs?
faq.answer: Limits depend on memory and algorithm choice; very large graphs can be slow or require sparse matrices.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with pandas or NumPy?
faq.answer: Yes, examples show converting between DataFrames, NumPy arrays, and NetworkX graphs.

faq.question: Does it access my files or credentials?
faq.answer: No, it only shows local code examples and does not access sensitive files.

faq.question: What should I do if an import fails?
faq.answer: Install NetworkX and optional libraries like matplotlib, then retry the import.

faq.question: How does this compare to graph databases?
faq.answer: NetworkX is in memory and code focused, while graph databases provide persistent storage and query languages.
